content: The Navajo Reservation boundary is clarified to include trust lands of the Navajo Tribe as of January 1, 2014. Land reselection is allowed to correct surveying errors. The Navajo Tribe has the right to deselect and reselect up to 757 acres of land to correct surveying errors. Deselected trust land will be administered by the Bureau of Land Management. Additionally, a report on fair rental value payments is required. The Secretary of the Interior must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of this Act, detailing rental decisions between the Navajo and Hopi Tribes from 2001 to 2013. It should include explanations for any delays and the current status of rental determinations, including pending appeals. The report to Congress must detail rental decisions between the Navajo and Hopi Tribes from 2001 to 2013, including explanations for delays and the status of pending appeals. It should also address the role of contracts with the Bureau of Indian Affairs under the Indian Self-Determination Act and ensure contractor performance is free from conflicts of interest. The report to Congress must include details on rental payments by the Navajo Tribe, plans to update rental determinations, and ensure timely delivery of annual rental determinations to both the Navajo and Hopi Tribes. The Navajo Tribe sovereignty empowerment demonstration project is outlined in Section 4. The Navajo Tribe can designate up to 150,000 acres as Navajo Sovereignty Empowerment Zones within specific areas of the Navajo Reservation. This includes lands selected under previous acts and lands partitioned to the tribe. Within the Navajo Sovereignty Empowerment Zones, certain laws are waived for renewable energy, housing, public facilities, and infrastructure development, including the Wilderness Act, National Environmental Policy Act, Endangered Species Act, National Historic Preservation Act, and others. The curr_chunk lists various federal acts including the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, National Wildlife Refuge System Administration Act of 1966, Fish and Wildlife Act of 1956, Fish and Wildlife Coordination Act, Administrative Procedure Act, National Park Service Organic Act, General Authorities Act of 1970, National Parks and Recreation Act of 1978, and Arizona Desert Wilderness Act of 1990. The Arizona Desert Wilderness Act of 1990 (16 U.S.C. 1132 note; Public Law 101-628) does not supersede Navajo Nation laws or treaties with the United States. It also does not waive the Navajo-Hopi Dispute Settlement Act of 1996 or affect the Navajo Tribe's eligibility for funding and grants. SEC. 13. RELINQUISHMENT OF ACCOMMODATION AGREEMENT AND ELIGIBILITY FOR RELOCATION BENEFITS. Navajo head of household can relinquish Accommodation Agreement within two years and receive full relocation benefits, including housing and counseling. Successor can also receive benefits if original head is no longer in that role. The Navajo head of household can relinquish the Accommodation Agreement within two years to receive full relocation benefits, including housing and counseling. The relinquishment does not go into effect until the Office of Navajo and Hopi Indian Relocation provides the benefits to the Navajo head of household or their successor. SEC. 6. NAVAJO REHABILITATION TRUST FUND. Section 32 of Public Law 93-531 is amended to allow the Navajo Tribe to use funds for development in the Navajo Sovereignty Empowerment Zones. Additionally, changes are made to subsections (f) and (g) of the law.
